question.questionText: When you build a series circuit using 2 bulbs and one D-cell, the bulbs are very dim. When you build a parallel circuit with 2 bulbs and one D-cell, the bulbs are bright. Why are the bulbs dim in series and bright in parallel?

referenceAnswers.referenceAnswer: In series, the 2 bulbs have to share one pathway, so the light is dim. In parallel each bulb has a direct path to the D-cell energy source so both bulbs shine brightly.

studentAnswers.studentAnswer: The bulbs are dim in the series because they have to share electricity. They are bright in a parallel circuit because they have their own pathway.
The bulbs are dim because they have to share a path. They are bright because they do not have to share a pathway.
